pageContext.claim: “They cut off banking to North Korea. That is something they've never done before. They cut away down on the full fuel.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump goes too far to say such action has never been done. In 2005, after the U.S. Treasury Department accused Macau-based Banco Delta Asia as being a willing pawn for North Korean money-laundering, the People's Bank of China ordered the closure of North Korean accounts in major Chinese banks. The effort was undone after the George W. Bush administration, seeking to reopen talks with Pyongyang, in 2007 facilitated the return of frozen North Korean funds held in BDA.
